In her early 30s, Meghan began to pursue a career in television and acting, landing small roles in shows like "Castle" and "Suits." Her breakout role came in 2011 when she played Rachel Zane, a paralegal, in the popular USA Network series "Suits." Meghan's performances earned her several award nominations, including a nomination for the 2016 People's Choice Award for Favorite TV Dramatic Actress.

On November 27, 2017, Meghan's life took a dramatic turn when she began dating Prince Harry, the Duke of Sussex, a member of the British royal family. Their whirlwind romance sparked global interest, and the couple announced their engagement in December 2017. On May 19, 2018, Meghan became the Duchess of Sussex when she married Prince Harry at St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.

As the Duchess of Sussex, Meghan has been involved in various charitable initiatives, including supporting women's empowerment, education, and conservation. She has also been a vocal advocate for mental health awareness and has worked to promote diversity and inclusivity within the British royal family.

In 2020, Meghan and Prince Harry announced that they would be stepping back from their royal duties and pursuing a more private life. The couple has since moved to California, where they are raising their two children, Archie Mountbatten-Windsor (born in 2019) and Lilibet Mountbatten-Windsor (born in 2021).
